description.value:
As a thief, you have the following class characteristics.

Hit Points

Hit Dice: 1d8 per thief level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per thief level after 1st

Proficiencies

Armor: Light armor
Weapons: Simple weapons, hand crossbows, longswords, rapiers, shortswords
Tools: Thieves' tools
Saving Throws: Dexterity, Intelligence
Skills: Choose four from Acrobatics, Athletics, Deception, Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Perception, Performance, Persuasion, Sleight of Hand, and Stealth

Equipment

You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) a @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.RHMetzUXa1H3anMj]{Rapier} or (b) a @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.zKCfTMLmn1AjBucu]{Shortsword}
  • (a) a @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.REXaAPkxGwpNr8Dp]{Shortbow} and a quiver of 20 @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.AGek4JacYSANuCjI]{Arrows} or (b) a @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.zKCfTMLmn1AjBucu]{Shortsword}
  • (a) a @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.OSfgYHFuiL4mhuY7]{Burglar's Pack}, (b) a @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.pI51kNF0SPoi13po]{Dungeoneer's Pack}, or (c) a @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.DndDRdbpbQp6Ey5i]{Explorer's Pack}
  • (a) @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.uLEl8peGi41lV5YH]{Leather Armor}, two @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.QrHS8FqbAi0Lsk9J]{Daggers}, and @Compendium[5e-complete-fr.5e-items.HWphIyqLmXJ56fRh]{Thieves' Tools}

Alternatively, you can roll [[/roll 3d4 * 10]] gp and buy all your equipment.

Note: This is a rebalanced roll calculated by thinkdm.org. The canon roll is [[/roll 4d4 * 10]].

The Thief

Signaling to her companions to wait, a half-elf slips down the dungeon corridor. She presses an ear to the door, then pulls out a set of tools and picks the lock in a flash. Then she vanishes into the shadows as her warrior friend advances to kick in the door.

A human lurks in the shadows of an alley while his accomplice prepares for his part of the ambush. When their target—a notorious slaver—passes by the alley, the accomplice shouts, the slaver comes to investigate, and the assassin's blade slits his throat before he can make a sound.

Suppressing a giggle, a gnome wiggles her fingers and magically lifts the ring of keys from the guard's belt. In an instant, the keys are in her hand, the cell door is open, and she and her companions are free to escape.

Thieves rely on skill, stealth, and the vulnerabilities of their enemies to gain the advantage in any situation. They have a knack for finding the solution to almost any problem, demonstrating ingenuity and versatility that are the cornerstone of any successful adventuring party.

Skill and Precision

Thieves devote as much effort to mastering the use of a variety of skills as they do to honing their combat capabilities, giving them a broad expertise that few other characters can match. Many thieves focus on stealth and deception, while others refine the skills that aid them in a dungeon environment, such as climbing, finding and disabling traps, and picking locks.

When it comes to combat, thieves favor guile over brute force. A thief prefers to make a precise strike, placing it exactly where the attack will do the most damage to the target, rather than wearing down an opponent with a flurry of attacks. Thieves have an almost supernatural knack for avoiding danger, and some learn magical tricks to complement their other abilities.

A Life of Shadows

Every city and town has its share of thieves. Most of them fit the worst stereotypes of the class, earning their living as burglars, assassins, cutpurses, and con artists. Often, these scoundrels are organized into thieves' guilds or criminal families. Many thieves operate independently, but even they sometimes recruit apprentices to help with their cons and burglaries. Some thieves earn an honest living as locksmiths, investigators, or exterminators, which can be a dangerous job in a world where fierce rats—and were-rats—haunt the sewers.

As adventurers, thieves fall on both sides of the law. Some are hardened criminals who seek their fortune in treasures, while others take up a life of adventure to escape the law. Some have honed and perfected their skills with the express purpose of infiltrating ancient ruins and hidden crypts in search of treasure.

Multiclassing

If your group uses the optional multiclassing rule in the Player's Handbook, here is what you need to know if you choose thief as one of your classes.

Minimum ability score. As a multiclass character, you must have at least a 13 Dexterity to take a level in this class, or to take a level in another class if you are already a thief.

Proficiencies gained. If thief is not your initial class, here are the proficiencies you gain when you take your first level as a thief: light armor, one skill from the class's skill list, thieves' tools.

Spell slots. If you take the Arcane Trickster subclass you are a third spellcaster. Add one-third of your levels (rounded down) in the thief class to the appropriate levels of other classes to determine your available spell slots.

Please refer to the @UUID[Compendium.5e-complete-fr.5e-journals.a5xwmx4d5X1FHEct]{Multiclassing Rules} for additional information on multiclassing.
